titlestmt.titleproper: Bertie Routh Barron papers, Inclusive: 1897-1972, undated, Bulk: 1897-1900

note.p: © 2021 The Texas Collection. All rights reserved.

profiledesc.creation: Finding Aid was generated by The Texas Collection staff, using the STAR Knowledge Center for Archives (SKCA) task that automatically creates EAD files from the Archive's SKCA catalog records.

did.head: Papers Summary
did.abstract: The Bertie Routh Barron papers contains correspondence, financial documents, literary productions and photographic materials pertaining to the life of Bertie Routh Barron, particularly the time she spent at Baylor Female College.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Bertie Routh Barron was born in Plano, Texas, in 1880 to James M. and Virginia "Jennie" Barron. Her family was active at First Baptist Church Plano, so it is not surprising that she would attend a Baptist college. After graduating from Baylor Female College in 1900, Bertie went on to marry Alanzo Webb and the couple had one child, Robert B. Webb. Bertie Routh Barron passed away in 1916.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Bertie Routh Barron Papers include correspondence, financial statements regarding Bertie's expenses while at Baylor Female College, a history of the Jacob Routh Pioneer Cemetery as well as a history of First Baptist Church of Plano. This collection begins in 1897, when Bertie moves to Belton. The Correspondence series is by far the largest series of the collection. Also included are portraits of Bertie Barron and her parents, James M. and Virginia "Jennie" Barron.

Bertie Routh Barron attended Baylor Female College for three years in the 1890s. Baylor Female College would eventually become the University of Mary Hardin-Baylor. Barron wrote many letters to her family in Plano, Texas, during her time in Belton, and it is these letters that serve as a centerpiece for this collection. These papers are unique in that they provide an insight into women's higher education during the turn of the century.

During her time at Baylor Female College, Bertie wrote of many aspects of life in the female college. She recounts her experiences with professors, meals, grades, church, roommates, and traveling, allowing the reader a window into her world. Other documents and photographs included in these papers describe college grading, the costs of attending college, and relationships within the Barron family.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Prior to this finding aid, the Bertie Routh Barron papers were organized chronologically and according to type. A comprehensive inventory was available, and a finding aid had been written. This collection is arranged in four series: I. Correspondence, II. Financial Documents, III. Literary Materials, and IV: Photographic Materials.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to The Texas Collection in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Bertie Routh Barron papers, Accession #245, Box #, Folder #, The Texas Collection, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Adina Johnson. Released on 2012-12-20.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series contains correspondence from and about Bertie Routh Barron accounting for her time spent at Baylor Female College. Within the correspondence, Bertie relates stories of her academic pursuits, friendships and living conditions at the university. This series also includes correspondence from Baylor Female College to Bertie’s father, James M. Barron and various correspondence from Barron family members. This is the largest series in the Bertie Routh Barron Papers. It is in good condition.

did.unittitle: Baylor Female College to James M. Barron

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series includes financial statements from Baylor Female College regarding Bertie’s schooling. Included are listings of all expenses she incurred. This series is in excellent condition.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series includes grade reports, newspaper clippings and two essays regarding Bertie Routh Barron’s matriculation at Baylor Female College. This series is in good condition.

did.unittitle: History of First Baptist Church in Plano
Keith Krawczynski: ”Bertie Baylor: Student Life at Baylor Female College in the Late 1890s"

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series includes portraits of Bertie Routh Barron and her parents, James M. and Virginia “Jennie” Barron. This series is in good condition.
